claim: The capital of France is Paris

supporting.text: Paris has been the capital of France since the 10th century.

attacks.text: Paris has been the capital of France since the 10th century.
During World War II, the capital of France was temporarily moved to Vichy.
The Vichy government was not the legitimate government of France, and Paris remained the symbolic capital.
Historical records from the 10th century are incomplete, making it uncertain when Paris officially became the capital.
Multiple reputable historical sources confirm Paris's status as the capital since the 10th century.

supporting.text: The French government and its administrative institutions are headquartered in Paris.

attacks.text: The French government and its administrative institutions are headquartered in Paris.
Some administrative functions are decentralized to other cities like Lyon or Marseille.
The core institutions (Presidency, Parliament, etc.) remain exclusively in Paris, maintaining its status as the capital.
Historical capitals like Vichy (1940-1944) temporarily replaced Paris.
Vichy's status was never internationally recognized as France's legal capital during WWII.

supporting.text: International organizations and diplomatic missions recognize Paris as the capital of France.

attacks.text: International organizations and diplomatic missions recognize Paris as the capital of France.
Some unrecognized or disputed entities may not acknowledge Paris as the capital of France.
The vast majority of sovereign states and international bodies recognize Paris as the capital, making non-recognition statistically insignificant.
Historical records show that other cities, such as Vichy, temporarily served as the capital of France during wartime.
These were temporary and exceptional circumstances, not altering the established and continuous status of Paris as the capital.

supporting.text: Historical records and official documents consistently identify Paris as the capital of France.

attacks.text: Historical records and official documents consistently identify Paris as the capital of France.
During the German occupation in WWII, the Vichy regime temporarily moved the capital to Vichy.
The Vichy regime was not internationally recognized as the legitimate government of France, and Paris remained the de jure capital.
Some historical texts refer to Versailles as the capital during the reign of Louis XIV.
Versailles was the seat of government but not officially designated as the capital; Paris retained its status.
